context: The primary source of rain in the Sahara is <b12_0>the equatorial low<b12_0/> a continuous belt of <a0_0>low-pressure systems<a0_0/> <b4_0>near the equator<b4_0/> which bring the brief, short and irregular rainy season to the Sahel and the southern Sahara. The Sahara doesn't <b8_0>lack precipitation<b8_0/> because of a lack of moisture, but due to the <a1_0><b5_0>lack of a precipitation-generating mechanism<b5_0/><a1_0/>. Rainfall in this giant desert has to overcome the <b6_0>physical and atmospheric <a2_0>barriers<b6_0/> that normally prevent <b9_0>the production of precipitation<b9_0/><a2_0/>. The harsh climate of <b7_0><b10_0>the Sahara<b10_0/><b7_0/> is characterized by extremely low, unreliable, highly erratic rainfall; extremely high sunshine duration values; <a3_0>high temperatures <b11_0>year-round<b11_0/><a3_0/>; negligible rates of relative humidity, a significant diurnal temperature variation and extremely high levels of potential evaporation which are the highest recorded worldwide.
